awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Single molecule characterization and controlled transport using lysenin channels inserted into lipid membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary
This CAREER award from the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research to Boise State University is to study biophysical properties of a specific pore-forming protein isolated from earthworms. These pore forming proteins will be studied for their unique control over the transport of relevant molecules. The scientific broader impact of this project is the development of efficient methodologies for molecular identification, single-molecule analysis, design of nano-containers for controlled delivery of chemicals and drugs, and cell loading through temporary membrane permeabilization. The research activities will be incorporated into interdisciplinary teaching and mentoring practices for high-school, undergraduate and graduate students. Specific student recruitment approaches are in place to ensure participation of women, underrepresented, and economically disadvantaged students in research and education. The investigator will be actively engaged in outreach activities at local schools and educational centers, will develop the students' ability to effectively share their interest in science, and to energize young students to pursue STEM careers and to cultivate a greater understanding and appreciation of the merits of scientific research.   

Technical Summary
The research objective of this CAREER award is to investigate the ability of the pore-forming protein lysenin isolated from earthworms to function as either a nano-sensing device or as nano-valve actuated by physical or chemical stimuli. The large size of the lysenin pore opening will enable use of the resistive pulse technique for stochastic sensing, and single-molecule detection and characterization. Reversible ligand-gating induced by multivalent cations is exploited to achieve exquisite control over the transport of molecules across artificial lipid membranes that are being prepared. Specific aims of the project are; 1) to investigate the transport of macromolecules through lysenin channels inserted into artificial membranes; 2) to initiate and control the transport through artificial lipid membranes with lysenin channels; and 3) to exploit lysenin voltage regulation for reversible control over cell membrane permeability and to develop an understanding of the conducting state of lysenin channels with external electric fields. These studies would advance and significantly transform the current techniques and methodologies employed for fast and reliable molecular sizing, single-molecule analysis and sequencing, design of nano-containers for controlled delivery of chemicals and drugs, and cell loading through temporary membrane permeabilization. The project includes a detailed and carefully tailored plan for recruiting, mentoring and teaching of students, and outreach activities. Undergraduate, graduate, and high-school students will actively participate in this cutting-edge interdisciplinary research utilizing electrophysiology, fluorescence spectroscopy, and molecular biology techniques. The outreach activities developed with the participant students are expected to cultivate a greater understanding of the merits of scientific research to the public and mobilize young students to pursue careers in STEM areas.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major research goal of this project was to demonstrate the hypothesis that lysenin channels inserted into natural and artificial lipid membranes may function both as single molecule nano-sensors and as nano-valves actuated by external physical or chemical stimuli for the purpose of controlled transport of ions and molecules across membranes. The educational goal of the project was to build a solid foundation of integrated STEM teaching, learning, outreach, and scientific discovery aimed towards better understanding the functionality of biomolecules, enabling further development into methodologies and techniques that will impact biosciences and biotechnologies.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes. We exploited the ability of lysenin channels to insert large conductance channels into natural and artificial lipid membranes and their reversible and irreversible regulation by physical and chemical stimuli for development of applications ranging from sensing to controlled transport and bioelectronics. We showed that lysenin channels reconstituted into bilayer lipid membranes may be used as biosensors for rapid detection of multivalent metal ions in solutions at sub-nM concentrations. A single lysenin channel inserted into an artificial membrane demonstrated exceptional capabilities for single molecule detection and characterization, which may be exploited for rapid DNA and protein sequencing. The large size of the lysenin channel and its irreversible blockage by cationic polymers enabled access of large, non-permeant molecules to the cytosol; subsequent channel blockage by addition of chitosan reinstated the barrier function of the membrane and preserved the cellular viability. This non-destructive approach of temporary permeabilization is anticipated to have a great impact on applications such as genetic engineering, manipulation of biological functions within cells, imaging, and drug delivery for targeted therapy. Our team found that lysenin channels have ionic selectivity; therefore, they may be used to modulate the resting potential of excitable and non-excitable cells. In the same line, the unique regulatory features of lysenin channels led to the discovery that the selectivity for monovalent ions is altered when the channels are forced to adopt a sub-conducting state, providing insight into how protein channels may adjust their permeability and biological functionality beyond the traditional open-close model. Our extensive research on the response presented by the regulatory response of lysenin channels to oscillatory voltages concluded that the assembled channel behaves like a molecular memory completely controlled by external electrical stimulation. The research from this project was included in twelve peer-reviewed articles and over fifty poster and oral presentations made at local, regional, and national scientific meetings.

Broader Impacts Outcomes. This project provided opportunities for the engagement of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in hands-on research experience in a real lab setup. For its entire duration, the project engaged twenty high school students, fifty-five undergraduate students, and seventeen graduate students. Thirteen graduate students were directly supervised by the PI, and ten of them have graduated with support from this project. Twenty-seven of the undergraduate students pursued further education through medical and graduate schools, and twenty more are expected to graduate and continue with higher education in the next two years. All of the high school students who graduated have been accepted for college education. Among many others, the list of student achievements includes three national graduate fellowships, an NSF-postdoc fellowship, an NSF-B2D fellowship, one Goldwater scholarship, two INBRE summer fellowships, one RAIN summer fellowship, two LSAMP fellowships, two HERC scholarships, two Sigma-Xi scholarships, four McNair scholarships, two Top Ten Scholars, and three travel awards -to the Biophysical Society meetings. Over 50% of the students participating in research and educational activities from this project belong to underrepresented groups and minorities. The multidisciplinary nature of the research appealed to students with backgrounds in Physics, Math, Biology, Chemistry, Health Sciences, Anthropology, Engineering, Music, and Performance. All the students were given the opportunity to contribute to the dissemination of their work through co-authored articles and presentations.

The inclusive and diverse educational and research environment made possible through this project led to the development of successful outreach programs for science communication, STEM recruitment, and the improvement of scientific literacy of the public at large. The participating students engaged in numerous scientific presentations at local and regional schools and public libraries, peer training, tutoring, supervision, and mentoring.The participating students presented their work to high school students and visitors during on-site visits. 

Results and methodologies derived from this project have been successfully included in two undergraduate biophysics classes, one undergraduate lab, and one graduate class. A major portion of the topics approached in this project will be included in a new multidisciplinary class intended for the newly developed undergraduate degree in Biomolecular Sciences at our institution. This project also provided the opportunity to test, adapt, and adopt the best teaching and instructional practices in online, remote, and in-person activities.  


Last Modified: 04/20/2023
Modified by: Daniel Fologea

Image
  • (A) ATDC5 cells exposed to lysenin, AF546-Pha, and calcein-AM under transmitted light. (B) The red AF546-Phal was detected inside the lysenin-permeabilized cells. (C) The green fluorescence indicated that the cells remained viable. (D) Overlap of transmitted, red, and green channel images.
    Authors
    Creative Commons
    Daniel Fologea
    Temporary permeabilization via lysenin channels.
